Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Implementation and Impact of RDE Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
?The project focuses on the evaluation of awards that were part of the 2011 cohort of research and demonstration projects funded by the Research in Disabilities Education program. The evaluation has two objectives: (1) To describe the challenges to and facilitators of research on disabilities education experienced by the projects; (2) To assess the nature and extent of dissemination and application of the results beyond the funded research context. The evaluation utilizes a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods, including systematic reviews of project documents and interviews with project researchers.

The project is developing a composite program logic model that incorporates the activities and intended outcomes of the different research and demonstration projects, and links them to the goals of the NSF program. By looking across projects, the evaluation is supporting more general conclusions about the conduct of funded research in disabilities education than can be drawn from a disparate set of individual project evaluations.
The evaluation will have a broader impact on the participation of people with disabilities in STEM education and careers by strengthening current research projects with formative feedback on methodological issues. Researchers in disabilities education will be able to use the findings to inform the research, dissemination, and evaluation plans they propose in future projects.
Findings are expected to provide vital information to field of research in disabilities education investigators for evaluating research in STEM education of students with disabilities.?

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study was originally intended to compile and synthesize the evidence across four Research in Disabilities (RDE) projects funded by NSF of actual or potential influence on the number of students with disabilities completing STEM degrees and entering the US science and engineering workforce. The four projects varied substantially in their purpose, scope, and the age groups and disabilities of the students included in the sample. It was therefore not feasible to synthesize across the four individual projects. Instead, the study was redirected to identify and explore methodological issues that challenged the conduct of studies with students with disabilities. Two rounds of interviews were conducted with the four PIs. Five challenges were identified including the purpose of the four projects (i.e., fundamental research versus implementation research), definition of disability (i.e., particular age group [K-12 vs. post-secondary], the use of assessments vs. self-reports, and the educational context in which students were functioning), study recruitment of subjects (i.e.., cultivating school-level relationships, challenges to securing individuals’ participation, and incentivizing participation), sample size and impact on research design (i.e., sample size, inclusion of non-intervention group, federal preference for quantitative designs, and retention and attrition), and research study parameters (I.e., length of time, alignment between NSF and intervention cycles, researcher training, adapting equipment, and project dissemination). These challenges were explored more fully in the report. In addition, recommendations were offered for both NSF and PIs seeing NSF funding.


Last Modified: 10/12/2015
Modified by: Joan Buttram
